Glycemic Index Of Sago

Sago is a starchy food that is derived from the pith of the sago palm tree. It is commonly used in various cuisines around the world, particularly in Southeast Asia. Sago is often used as a thickening agent in desserts, soups, and other dishes. However, one aspect of sago that is often overlooked is its glycemic index.

The glycemic index (GI) is a measure of how quickly a carbohydrate-containing food raises blood sugar levels. Foods with a high GI are quickly digested and absorbed, causing a rapid increase in blood sugar levels. On the other hand, foods with a low GI are digested and absorbed more slowly, resulting in a slower and more gradual increase in blood sugar levels.

The GI of sago is relatively high, with a value of around 70. This means that consuming sago can cause a rapid increase in blood sugar levels. This is particularly important for individuals with diabetes or those who are trying to manage their blood sugar levels. Consuming foods with a high GI can lead to spikes in blood sugar levels, which can be detrimental to overall health.

However, it is important to note that the GI of a food is not the only factor to consider when evaluating its impact on blood sugar levels. The glycemic load (GL) is another important measure that takes into account both the GI and the amount of carbohydrates in a serving of food. The GL provides a more accurate representation of how a food will affect blood sugar levels.

In the case of sago, the GL is relatively low. This is because sago is typically consumed in small quantities and is often combined with other ingredients that can help to lower its overall impact on blood sugar levels. For example, sago is commonly used in desserts that also contain fats, proteins, and fiber, all of which can help to slow down the digestion and absorption of carbohydrates.

Additionally, the way sago is prepared can also affect its glycemic impact. Cooking sago for a longer period of time can increase its resistance to digestion, resulting in a lower GI. Soaking sago before cooking can also help to reduce its GI.

Despite its relatively high GI, sago can still be enjoyed as part of a balanced diet. It is important to consume sago in moderation and to pair it with other foods that can help to slow down its digestion and absorption. This can include adding fats, proteins, and fiber to sago-based dishes.
